title: theresa may must think about brexit 2019
story: Between attempting to get a deal that works for Britain and preparing for a No Deal if Brussels bureaucrats remain so inflexible, there is PLENTY of work to do over the coming months.Thinking about four years’ time is an unnecessary distraction.For one thing she needs to insist that her civil servants — and some of her Cabinet colleagues — get with the programme. Many of them need to listen to Sir Christopher Meyer, a former Remainer who is now looking forward to a brighter future free of the EU’s iron grip.It is crucial that everybody involved in these next vital months of negotiations is genuinely ambitious about what Britain can be as a truly independent country.We have the fifth-largest economy in the world and we’re a “soft-power” titan.There might be people in Brussels who think we are doomed to failure once we leave — but there shouldn’t be any ­sitting on our side of the table.If the Government prepares us properly for a clean break over the coming months, we’ve no reason to be scared for the future. It will strengthen our hand in negotiations, too.So get on with THAT, Prime Minister.THE Russian bear is roaring, and we don’t seem ready to defend ourselves.Today a respected intelligence expert suggests our border control could have been hacked by Russian spies in the run-up to the Salisbury attack.The Prime Minister has been admirably tough with the Kremlin, even if Jeremy Corbyn and other useful idiots have attempted to undermine her and our ­national security at every turn.But there is no room for complacency. There are serious concerns that our defence budget isn’t sufficient — and that the Treasury is worried the MoD wouldn’t know what to do with any additional cash.We are in a digital war and we cannot afford to lose it.THE feelgood factor from England’s World Cup campaign keeps on going.As if uniting the country for those few weeks wasn’t enough­, the players have donated their match fees to charity.It’s true to say they won’t miss the cash but it’s a gesture that sums up this new England team.Well played, lads.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: christmas shops early ban ukip gerard batten
story: Gerard Batten blasted supermarkets for putting festive treats on the shelves already - nearly four months before December 25.He told The Sun firms are ruining childrens enjoyment of Christmas by promoting it so aggressively.Mr Battens tirade came after he found festive shortbread and chocolate Santas on sale in a brance of Tesco over the weekend.He wrote on Twitter: I’m in Tesco, it’s 8th September and they are already selling Christmas stuff. Chocolate Father Christmas’ and all.I’m tempted by the mince pies but what does four months of this do to a child’s perception of Christmas before the big day? There should be law against it!Asked if he was seriously proposing a legal ban on the promotions, Mr Batten told The Sun he was being tongue in cheek - but added that the Government should consider cracking down.He said: I was being humorous when I said that there should be a law against it, but it is wrong that Christmas is commercialised in early September.It spoils it for children for whom it should be an exciting and special event. But, just maybe, we should have a law.Last week Ukip called on Brits to boycott the military - because some soldiers have the EU flag on their uniform.Mr Batten said citizens should refused to join the armed forces until after Brexit.

title: theresa may branded embarrassing by her own mp because she wont support the armed forces
story: The Sun can reveal former squaddie Johnny Mercer ripped into the PM’s chief of staff in the Commons – claiming the Government was refusing to back the military.Sources claimed he hit back at Gavin Barwell after being challenged why he was so critical of the Government’s record. And the MP told the aide he had “given up” on Downing Street.The shouting match is thought to have occurred after Prime Minister’s Questions last Wednesday.A source said: “Johnny lost it. Gavin asked what he was playing at.“Johnny gave it to him with both barrels, jabbing his finger and saying how the PM and No.10 were embarrassing him and he could no longer defend his own Government when he speaks to people in the military.”Mr Mercer – MP for Plymouth Moor – served as a captain with 29 Commando Regiment Royal Artillery in Afghanistan.Last week he accused the PM of “not getting it” over the Government’s refusal to offer Army veterans facing prosecution for killings in Northern Ireland an amnesty.Mr Barwell is believed to have challenged the MP over the comments.MPs are also furious at Theresa May’s repeated failure to commit to the UK remaining a “tier one” military power.In June, the PM sparked suggestions of spending cuts by only saying she was committed to Britain remaining a “leading military power”.Tory backbenchers are also livid with the appointment of Stuart Andrew as ministerial aide at the Ministry of Defence two months ago. One told The Sun: “He has no experience whatsoever. But he’s been put in charge of equipment and defence exports.”Mr Mercer declined to comment last night.

title: hunt for cruel dog owner country road
story: Some of the puppies still didnt have their eyes open as animal welfare officers launched an appeal to hunt down the owner with fears about the health of the mum dog.The 10 Staffordshire bull terrier pups, believed to be 10-days old, were found in a plastic box in Titchfield Lane, near Wickham, Hampshire on Saturday night.They were rushed to a vet for immediate treatment where they were then having to be hand-fed.RSPCA inspectors are worried about the health of the mum of the pups who could now be suffering from mastitis having delivered so many.Charlotte Coggins, who is investigating for the animal welfare charity, said: Its estimated the puppies are around 10 days old. They are tiny, they dont yet have their eyes open and need help feeding.Thankfully they are now getting the care they need and we hope they will all make a good recovery.We are very worried about the welfare of the mother dog as she will no doubt be really missing her pups, and could be suffering from mastitis after recently having so many puppies.I assume as theyd been left in the layby by the person responsible in the hope they would be found and helped.However, leaving such young puppies exposed like this without the mum they so desperately need risked their lives.Anyone with any information can call me in complete confidence on our inspectors appeal line on 0300 123 8018.

title: theresa may child support payments scrap
story: Campaigners last night demanded Downing Street intervene amid rising uproar over the proposals from the Department of Work and Pensions.The Government wants to write off money owed to 970,000 single parents in legacy cases over the past 20 years even though some claims are still contested.It argues it’s not cost effective to attempt to chase the money.The plans will absolve non-paying parents and leave short-changed parents with no way of going through the courts for compensation.Outraged campaigners have compared the move to the Windrush fiasco in the Home Office earlier this year.Sophie Walker, leader of the Women’s Equality Party, said: “The government’s plan to write off child support payments is an insult to single parents across the UK – especially those who are struggling to afford to give their kids the life they deserve.“Despite having the powers to collect the debts the Government seems more worried about the cost of maintaining records of it.”The Government consulted on the changes in December last year then confirmed its plans two months ago – and now wants to push it through Parliament.Most of the 970,000 cases date back to the Child Support Agency, created in 1993 to free family courts from child maintenance cases.Single parents have it tough. They should have the Government’s unquestioned backing when former partners leech on their child support obligations.The reasoning behind this decision might appear obvious on a spreadsheet that shows the cost of pursuing old cases isn’t worth the hassle.But you try telling that to a mum or dad trying to make ends meet.How civil servants managed to botch the administration of this scheme is an important question, but for another time.Right now the Government need to stick by people who need their support.The agency was closed in 2012 with arrears topping £3.7 billion - £2.5 billion to parents and just over £1 billion to the taxpayer.Since 2012 legacy cases have been pursued as “resources allow”.One Mum, Joanna Archer said: “The Government is planning to write-off £2.5 billion of arrears that isn’t even owed to them.“They claim that the records cost too much to archive and are in any case inaccurate. Whose fault is that? It makes you wonder if the whole point of drawing a line under the CSA and moving to the CMS was a cynical attempt to hide their incompetence.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mcdonalds croydon rat
story: The footage, which has been shared on social media, shows the rodent running across the restaurant floor as staff try to shoo it towards the front door with mops.More than 160,000 people have viewed the video taken by a customer at the Croydon branch on Friday and shared on Facebook.A spokesman for the restaurant said staff were able to chase the rat out before calling in pest control experts to check for more.The video was taken at the restaurant in Church Street.The spokesman told the Croydon Advertiser: Hygiene and cleanliness is of utmost importance to us.A rodent made a well-timed run through the front door but our staff reacted quickly to make sure the visit was a very brief one and ushered it out of the restaurant, unharmed.We immediately asked pest control experts to carry out a check of the restaurant, with further checks [also taking place] in recent days.All of these checks have confirmed no evidence of pest activity and we are confident that this is an isolated incident.Earlier this year a teenager was left disgusted after finding a dead bug in a McDonalds Chicken Legend.And an ex-McDonalds worker posted photos on Twitter last year of what he claimed were the mouldy innards of a McFlurry machine.

title: dna test lady lake carol park
story: It appeared the case was closed when Carol Park’s husband Gordon was jailed for her killing — then took his own life in an apparent admission of guilt.Yet after 42 years and three police investigations, there may be one more dramatic twist which could see Gordon Park posthumously cleared.Thanks to the tireless campaigning of his and Carol’s children, the Criminal Cases Review Commission is set to rule soon whether this case can go to the Court of Appeal.Son Jeremy and daughter Rachel — along with Park’s third wife Jennie — remain convinced that their dad is innocent of the 1976 murder.They believed spending the rest of his life behind bars for a crime he did not commit was too much for him to bear, with suicide his only way out.Jennie said at his inquest in 2013, three years after he was found hanged in his cell on his 66th birthday: “Prison was a dark place for him. He hated every minute of it.”Now 73, and still living in the house in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, she shared with Park, Jennie refuses to speak publicly about the case.Rachel and Jeremy, who once described his dad as a “big softie”, will not comment until their final appeal bid has run its course.Victim Carol’s side of the family were convinced the jury got it right when they found him guilty in 2005.Niece Kay Washford, 56, said yesterday: “If he was innocent he would have fought it and fought it.“His suicide absolutely seemed like an admission of guilt to us.“I’m not happy about this latest attempt at an appeal. What do they think they have found that would make a difference?“Nothing has changed in our minds. We remain convinced that the police got the right man. And we will carry on fighting for Carol. It doesn’t matter how long she has been gone. She was part of our family and she deserves justice.”Carol, 30, was killed with an ice axe, her body wrapped in plastic sheeting and dumped in Coniston Water in the Lake District.The ropes used to tie Carol’s body are central to the case, with Jeremy and Rachel hoping advances in technology will detect another person’s DNA on the knots or plastic wrapping.That could lead to a full appeal and, ultimately, the conviction being quashed.Any appeal would be a startling development in a story which began more than half a century ago, when Carol and Park were introduced by a mutual friend.It did not take long for Carol, then a teenager and town hall clerk, and Gordon, aged around 20 and working at his parents’ paint and wallpaper business, to fall in love.Their romance would repeatedly give way to rows and break-ups but they always got back together and, in 1967, became man and wife.They moved into Bluestones, a house which Park was building in the pretty village of Leece, near Barrow-in- Furness, Cumbria.It was there, according to police, where he would murder Carol nine years later in a fit of jealous rage.The family had already been shattered by one violent death when, in 1969, Carol’s sister Christine was throttled by her boyfriend, who was later jailed for life.Christine, 17, had a young daughter Vanessa, who Carol and Park agreed to adopt and bring up as their own.They went on to have Jeremy and Rachel but the demands of caring for three children put more strain on their worsening relationship.Park was so strict with his kids that he used an egg-timer to make sure they ate their vegetables quickly, cracking a cane on the table if they failed.With their rows becoming increasingly heated, Carol, a primary school teacher like her husband, felt trapped by his controlling nature and embarked on the first of a series of flings.She twice left home for other men but returned, unable to be without her children.At the height of the summer of 1976 the couple decided to take Vanessa, eight, Jeremy, six, and Rachel, five, to Blackpool for the day.Park later told police that on the morning of the July trip, Carol said she felt unwell and stayed at home.He said he took the kids on his own and that Carol had vanished by the time they got home that night.Strangely, he did not report her missing for six weeks.He would go on to say: “I expected that she had gone off with somebody else. She had done it several times before.I was not unduly worried. She was young, attractive, vivacious and quite capable of looking after herself.”AT Park’s trial, prosecutors admitted there was not one conclusive piece of evidence – such as DNA or CCTV – which convicted him.Rather there was a collection of circumstantial evidence which “points one way – that Park killed his wife”.This included tensions in the marriage. A friend once called at their house to help defuse a row and found Park sitting on Carol, pinning her to the floor.Prosecutors also had the statement of a tourist who was at the lake in July 1976 and remembered seeing a man matching Park’s description dropping a “bulky item” into the water.Carol’s body was trussed up with rope tied with knots used by sailors and climbers. Park was both, and ropes found at his home had expertly tied knots like those used to tie up Carol.A hammer was also found and had imprints on it matching marks on the flattened lead piping used to weigh down her body.Stones recovered from the lake bed near her body matched those found in walls at the couple’s home.While on remand after his first arrest, two prisoners claimed that Park admitted the murder to them.His delay in raising the alarm made detectives suspicious and they carefully searched the house, including the chest freezer in the garage, and questioned the children.Park was not arrested and the first investigation ran out of steam after six months.But the police let it be known that if her body was ever found, Park, who kept a boat called Sail Fish on Coniston Water, would be the prime suspect.That became a reality 21 years later, when members of the Kendal and Lakes Diving Club were exploring the lake bed at a remote spot 250 yards off Bailiff Wood, on the east side of the five-and-a-half-mile stretch of water.At first they thought they had found an outboard motor so did not bother to collect it until three days later.When they eventually brought it ashore in August 1997 they discovered it was a body.One of the divers, John Walsh, said shortly after the find: “We became suspicious when we had a better look after dragging it ashore.“Cord was tied all around and it had been deliberately weighted down. But it still came as a nasty shock when we were told we had discovered a body.“I hope I never see anything like it again.”Carol was found dressed in a blue baby-doll nightdress.Within days, dental checks identified the remains.Park was on holiday in France at the time with childhood sweetheart Jennie.She had become his wife four years earlier, after the end of his short-lived marriage to second wife Catherine Sillars.Park and Catherine tied the knot in 1981, two years after his marriage to Carol was officially dissolved while she was still a missing person.Park, who continued to be a keen sailor and had a 19ft yacht called Mrs J, was arrested on his return to England and charged with Carol’s murder.But prosecutors announced five months later that there was not enough evidence to proceed with the case.FROM the day Carol vanished to the day he killed himself 34 years later, Park never wavered from his story.He claimed she was alive when he and the children went to Blackpool for a day out and was gone when they returned home.Park thought she had gone off with a lover and although he never publicly pointed the finger, one of her former partners – who was never a suspect – claimed Park had tried to implicate him in her disappearance.By the time anyone knew Carol had been murdered – when her body was found in 1997 – his children were adults and he had been married to third wife Jennie for four years.They had only ever known him as a decent, law-abiding father and husband and had no reason to suspect he was capable of murder.With no compelling evidence to prove he was the killer, they have continued to support his innocence.Park was delighted to be released, urging the police not to give up the hunt for his former wife’s killer.He said after the news in 1998: “I did not kill Carol — and I want people to know the truth. I want to put the record straight and draw a line under these terrible events I want her murderer caught.After all I’ve been through, the police owe it to me.”Detectives never did give up the hunt and, whether Park knew it or not, he remained their prime suspect.In January 2004 he was arrested again and once more charged with her murder.The following year, after what was effectively the third investigation into Carol’s death, the case went to trial at Manchester Crown Court.The jury heard that stones found where Carol’s body had been dumped matched ones taken from the walls at the family home.The body had been tied with a series of intricate knots and Park was said to have knowledge of ropes and knots thanks to his love of sailing.He denied murder but was found guilty and jailed for life.The rift that has opened up between Carol’s family, Jeremy and Rachel since his suicide at HMP Garth, near Leyland, Lancs, in January 2010, is just another tragic aspect to a story that has so far refused to end.Will the final chapter see Park’s kids clear their dad’s name?GOT a story? title: hurricane florence state of emergency us states
story: Florence crossed the 74mph threshold from tropical storm to hurricane on Sunday morning, and by evening its winds were up to 85mph.Drawing energy from the warm water, it could be a fearsome Category 4 with winds of 130mph or more by Tuesday, the National Hurricane Center said.People up and down the south east coast have been warned to get their emergency kits ready, map out escape routes and fill sandbags as the governors of North and South Carolina and Virginia declared states of emergency.Red flags flying on beaches warned swimmers to stay out of waters already roiled by the distant storm, and cruise ships and Navy vessels were being steered out of harms way.The Miami-based hurricane agency said that it is too early to know what path the storm will take but that it could roll ashore in the Carolinas by Friday.Forecasters urged residents from South Carolina to the mid-Atlantic to get ready and not just for a direct blow against the coast.They warned that Florence could slow or stall after coming ashore, with some forecasting models showing it could unload a foot or two of rain in places, causing devastating inland flooding.South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster said: Pretend, assume, presume that a major hurricane is going to hit right smack dab in the middle of South Carolina and is going to go way inshore.The states emergency management agency said it is preparing for the possibility of a large-scale disaster.In Charleston, South Carolina, along the coast, city officials offered sandbags to residents.Myrtle Beach Mayor Brenda Bethune urged people to secure their homes but said its too early to know if evacuations will be ordered.Hardware stores and supermarkets were busy ringing up sales of bottled water, plywood and generators.Ryan Deeck, grocery department manager at a Walmart, told The Sun News: Literally, they are filling buggies full of water, shopping carts full of water.Theyre coming in and buying water and plates, and thats about all theyre buying.North Carolina officials started getting bulldozers and chain saws ready.Across the south east, people were urged to put together emergency supply kits, prepare their homes and research evacuation routes.The Navy planned to send ships from the Hampton Roads area of Virginia out to sea.Florida-based Carnival Cruise Line re-routed its cruise ships.

title: pac man clean up ocean
story: On Saturday, the £20m ocean-cleaning device headed from San Francisco Bay to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch - which now covers an area the size of France - located between Hawaii and California.System 001, developed by non-profit organisation Ocean Cleanup, consists of a 600-metre-long floater that sits at the surface of the water and a tapered 3-metre-deep skirt attached below.The tube is shaped into a horseshoe and will drift naturally with the currents and the winds. Because it will move faster than the bits of plastic in the water it will gather them into a small area. The trapped debris will be collected by a vessel every few months and taken to land to be recycled.It is designed to collect larger debris to stop it from breaking down in dangerous microplastics.The pioneering system has built in lanterns, radar reflectors, navigational signals, GPS, and anti-collision beacons. Solar panels help provide power the the systems.Dutch innovator Boyan Slat said his device is the best way to clean up the ocean todayIt took five years to design and was invented by 24-year-old Dutch innovator Boyan Slat who hopes it will fetch 80,000 tons of plastic in its first year. If successful, more systems will be rolled out to the Great Pacific Garbage Patch where it is estimated 1.8 trillion pieces of plastic weighing 80,000 metric tons are currently afloat.But the pac-man has received heavy criticism from members of the marine community who believe the device will not reach the tiny pieces of plastic which will sink to the bottom of the ocean. What’s more, while the system is designed for fish to go underneath, there are concerns creatures such as jellyfish which float on the water’s surface could get trapped in the device.But Dutch inventor Boyan Slat hit back at the criticism, saying: “I don’t think there’s much of a choice in what we’re trying to do.“Research shows the plastic doesn’t go away by itself and keeps fragmenting over the next few decades. If we don’t clean it up now, all of it will become micro plastics and then we are in a much worse state than we are today.“This is the best way we could figure out how to do it.“If there are better ways, we’d love to know.”If successful, The Ocean Cleanup project is pressing on with its plans and believes it could remove 90 per cent of ocean plastic by 2040.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: account frozen high pitched voice
story: Steven Dennis, 23, has a high-pitched voice and is often mistaken for a female on the phone.Last week his Santander bank account was frozen after call handlers doubted him.The 5ft 11in lad was forced to go to his local branch to prove he is male to unblock his account.Last year Steven of Chelmsford, Essex was also blocked by Barclays despite passing all of the security questions.He said its call handlers now have a note on his account warning them he sounds like a woman.Steven has had similar issues booking taxis and paying gas bills.He sought medical help but hormone level tests revealed no abnormalities and voice therapy failed to change his pitch. It is believed his feminine voice is due to tightness of muscles around the voice box.He said: “On the phone its very difficult. I’m 23 but I sound prepubescent.”Steven said he felt “humiliated” by the latest incident and filed a complaint to Santander.He explained: “The woman who took the call said, ‘you don’t sound like a Mr Steven Dennis’. I understand the reaction but it gets tiring and it gets me down.”Santander said: “We have apologised to Mr Dennis for the experience he received. It was certainly not our intention to cause any offence.”The incident came just days after transgender woman Sophia Reis was left in tears when her bank account was frozen because she sounded “like a man” over the phone.The 47-year-old was left “humiliated and embarrased” after banking staff said she failed security checks because she didn’t speak “like a lady”.Sophia, a customer service advisor from Nottingham, was forced to go to her local Santander branch to confront staff after the telephone ordeal.GOT a story? title: britains poshest student wants staff
story: The unknown daughter of an Indian billionaire has even been bought a mansion to live in instead of braving halls of residence.Her family have laid on the staff to ease her into her freshers’ week this week and during her four years at the university.She will also have a private chef and a chauffeur to whisk her from the mansion to her lectures and the student union at St Andrews in Scotland.Earlier this summer an ad for the maid asked for a “an outgoing, cheerful and energetic personality”.They’ll be responsible for “waking principal up, liaising with other staff regarding routine and schedule, assisting with grooming, wardrobe management and personal shopping”.The butler will oversee the team, while the footmen will be responsible for serving all meals daily, laying the table and keeping the house clean.They will also be required to open doors for the student “wherever possible”, the ad said.The ads were posted via posh agency Silver Swan recruitment.It said: “The family are very formal so want experienced staff.” The roles are said to pay about £30,000 a year. Silver Swan did not comment. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: jamie oliver face of tesco
story: It is the TV chef’s first supermarket role since quitting Sainsbury’s seven years ago.Jamie will give millions of customers tips on how they can improve their diet.His goods will contain less sugar, salt and fat and be 12 per cent cheaper than the chain’s standard range.He has repeatedly slammed the industry for promoting junk food and called for curbs on adverts and sugar.But Jamie, 43, who recently tackled a burglar at his home, told The Sun: “I’m more useful to the British public working with the biggest retailer because you want me on the inside.“Being able to affect how people shop is really powerful and I know it works.Where Tesco go, others will follow.”But Sophie Jarvis, of the Adam Smith Institute think tank, said: “Some of his policies are flawed and won’t make people eat healthier.”Tesco’s Alessandra Bellini said last night: “Together we want to make a real difference to our customers’ health.” GOT a story? title: nude art work men women
story: They spotted 64 todgers in paintings and sculptures but only 44 works showed female genitalia.There were nearly 200 naked women featured but most were depicted covering their modesty in tactful poses.However, they scored higher in the nipple count — with 196 pairs compared with 132 for the males.The stats emerged in The Sunday Times as many gallery bosses review their collections amid complaints of sexism against women.Analysts took the ­tallies in London’s National Gallery, Tate Britain, Royal Academy and ­Wallace Collection, plus Manchester Art Gallery.They have showcased some of the world’s most iconic nude artworks, including Michelangelo’s statue of Christ and The ­Toilet of Venus by Velazquez.In total, the researchers found 187 women displayed in nude or semi nude paintings and statues, and 119 men.Royal Academy boss Tim Marlow will ensure there are an equal number of male and female nudes in his gallery’s exhibition The Renaissance Nude, opening in March.But one art critic complained: “You can’t rewrite the history of art to make it more female-friendly.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits should work four days
story: She will demand laws letting unions enter Amazon and Google offices to force up pay.And she will insist a four-day week is the next goal for unions following victories for a two-day weekend and paid holidays in the last century.The TUC general secretary will tell the body’s 150th anniversary conference in Manchester: “I believe we can win a four-day working week, with decent pay for everyone.“It’s time to share the wealth from new technology. We need strong unions with the right to go into every workplace — starting with Amazon’s warehouses in the UK.”Research by the TUC showed that most workers expect managers and shareholders will reap the benefits of new technology.A survey of over 2,000 workers found that four out of five wanted to cut their working hours without loss of pay as new technology makes work more efficient.The TUC says moves should be made to cut the working week to four days over the course of this century.Employers were accused of making staff work unpredictable or unsocial hours because of an always on culture.Frances OGrady said too many firms were using technology to treat workers unfairly.Bosses and shareholders must not be allowed to hoover up all the gains from new tech for themselves.Working people deserve their fair share - and that means using the gains from new tech to raise pay and allow more time with their families, she said.If productivity gains from new technology are even half as good as promised then the country can afford to make working lives better. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: betfair punter winnings account paid
story: Carl Spencer spent months asking the bookie to cough up, and even sent them screen shots of the games he betted on.The 32-year-old placed online bets on the number of throw-ins or free kicks during certain periods of football matches.The Nottingham salesman said: “No money was going into my account for what I was sure had been winning bets.“Betfair insisted the games had been correctly logged. So I made recordings and took screen grabs of games I’d bet on.”Carl said he got his cash after six months — then his account was shut down. He recalled: “I kept on sending them and they eventually relented.” Carl said Betfair closed his account just before this summer’s World Cup.He added: “I think they were sick of me complaining all the time.”Betfair gets match stats from external companies. It said: “Where there is material evidence the information was inaccurate we formally resettle the market.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy hunt sparks tory leadership bid rumours after saying he backs brexit
story: The former Remain campaigner said his “views had changed” since getting his new Cabinet post and Brexit was “vital”.And he said ending Britain’s EU membership was the only way of restoring sovereignty and ensures decisions “are taken closer to the people they affect”.The comments in a Sunday newspaper column were immediately latched on by Eurosceptics. One said: “Forget Boris, Jeremy’s the one making a bid now.”It came as Home Secretary Sajid Javid said the rival Brexit plan pushed by arch Eurosceptics – a Canada style free trade deal – had a lot “to commend it”.Sources claimed former Chancellor George Osborne is advising the Tory rising star on a potential challenge.And yet another leadership contender, International Aid Secretary Penny Mordaunt staked her own claim by slamming the political elite.In a speech she said leaders had to inspire “participation and courage”.The blasts came ahead of yet another critical week for Brexit with Eurosceptics poised to finally launch their plans to destroy Theresa May’s soft Chequers compromise.The Eurosceptics led by Tory MPs Steve Baker and Jacob Rees Mogg will publish a blueprint for their way to solve the Northern Ireland-Irish border logjam on Wednesday.Arch Brexiteer sources yesterday angrily dismissed claims their other blueprints will contain calls for Brexit Britain to have its own ‘Stars Wars’ missile defence system and an expeditionary force for the Falklands.One senior Eurosceptic said: “This is Downing Street stirring it up. It’s rubbish.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: uk weather sunshine frosty winds low temperatures
story: Blustery showers are expected to hit Scotland before spreading south by the end of the week as Brits say a final goodbye to summer.Met Office meteorologist Alex Burkill told The Sun Online: This week will be chopping and changing with dry, warm periods but there will also be cold temperatures that will dip.It will be quite an autumnal week.He said fresher air was expected to see the mercury dip across southern parts of the UK.Temperatures will continue to cling to 25C tomorrow before they slide to a chilly 16C on Wednesday.Mr Burkill added: Tomorrow marks the boundary between slightly warmer air and fresher air that will push southwards.Thursday is looking mostly dry but with some blustery showers.He said nights were particularly expected to see a drop in temperatures, with mercury last night already dipping to lows of 8C.By the end of the week, blustery showers in Scotland will head further south.The Met Office has predicted unsettled conditions in the North and Central England from Tuesday onwards, with rain in the southeast at first, becoming cooler nationwide.Next week will feel warm in the South East, and is set to be brighter in Scotland, Northern Ireland and Northern England than elsewhere in the UK.The more typical September temperatures following months of blasting heat during Britains heatwave this summer.Brits experienced the hottest summer on record this year since records began in 2010.Elsewhere in the world, Hurricane Florence is expected to hit the US East Coast.Florence could potentially track more to the north, keeping it east of Bermuda and over the open waters of the central Atlantic next weekend and into the following week before being moved along by an eastward jet stream.The official hurricane season for the Atlantic Basin  is from June 1 to November 30.

title: new zealand earthquake magnitude kermadec islands
story: Thousands of people felt the massive quake 785km north-east of the mainland, reports RadioNZ.After the Ministry of Civil Defence initially warned the Kermadec tremor could trigger a tsunami, officials quickly quashed that possibility.In a tweet, the Ministry said: “There is no tsunami threat to New Zealand following the 6.8M earthquake SOUTH OF THE KERMADEC ISLANDS at 4.19pm. “Seismologist John Ristau said: People arent imagining that they felt anything, they did feel it.Theyre just feeling this large earthquake thats a few hundred kilometres away, north of the North Island.The colossal shaker was followed by a cluster of smaller tremors which shook the country – however an expert claims the smaller shakes are not related to the events in Kermadec, reports the NZ Herald.A Geonet spokesman said: “You cant make any guarantees but theres no reason to think this would trigger something on the Alpine Fault or any other major fault in New Zealand.”

title: prince harry tears helmand comrade ptsd
story: Warrant Officer Nathan Hunt, 39, protected the prince in Afghanistan and was mentioned in dispatches for saving hundreds of comrades.His grieving mum Maria met the the 33-year-old Royal, who completed two tours of duty fighting the Taliban in Helmand province, last week.She said newlywed Harry gave her a bear hug and had a tear on his cheek when they embraced at an event to raise money to help soldiers and veterans with mental health issues.Maria told The Daily Mail: I’d spent a week practising a little bow for when I met Harry, but he didn’t give me the chance. He just pulled me into his arms.When I looked up, Harry had a tear on his cheek. It was very emotional because he knew my son well. They went through a lot together. He is so warm and caring and so was Meghan.Maria said she and her husband Derek are still grieving for our Nathan but added: Harry remembered Nathan’s sense of humour and praised his professionalism.The Hunts met the Duke and Duchess of Sussex during the 100 Days To Peace concert last week.In July an Lincoln inquest heard the Royal Engineer was found hanged after not being properly trained for the nerve-racking combat role.An MOD spokesperson denied he was involved in clearing IEDs in Afghanistan.Passing a narrative verdict Paul Smith, the Area Coroner for Lincolnshire, said he could not be sure WO Hunt had intended to take his own life.Every 90 minutes in the UK a life is lost to suicide, the biggest killer of people under the age of 35.If you, or anyone you know, needs help dealing with mental health problems the Samaritans can be contacted on 116 123, or visit Mind’s website. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 80 tory mps ready to vote against pms chequers plan says ex brexit minister steve baker
story: With just 200 days to go to the scheduled date of Brexit, Mr Baker said that the PM would lack credibility with Brussels negotiators if she tried to press ahead with her departure plan at the upcoming Conservative conference without the backing of her party."When negotiating, the prime minister needs to demonstrate her intent and also her power to deliver," Mr Baker told the Press Association."If we come out of conference with her hoping to get Chequers through on the back of Labour votes, I think the EU negotiators would probably understand that if that were done, the Tory party would suffer the catastrophic split which thus far we have managed to avoid." Mr Baker said he was not advocating a change in leadership and said Tory critics of Chequers "do not want to be in a position of conflict with our own prime minister" and would give her "absolutely every support" in forging a free trade deal."Time is running awfully short for anyone who thinks a leadership contest and a general election is a good idea," said the Wycombe MP.But he said that, with Labour indicating it will vote against Mrs May's Brexit white paper package, it would be "fanciful" to expect her to secure parliamentary approval for Chequers.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2""We are reaching the point now where it is extremely difficult to see how we can rescue the Conservative Party from a catastrophic split if the Chequers proposals are carried forward," he said."It is absolutely no pleasure whatsoever to me to acknowledge that, but I look at the mood of colleagues and the mood of the Conservative party in the country and I am gravely concerned for the future of our party."I am gravely concerned because I recognise that the Labour opposition represents a severe danger to our security and our prosperity."Mr Baker said he hoped the Tories would come out of conference united behind a free trade agreement solutionto Britain's future relations with the EU. However, Justice Secretary David Gauke dismissed Mr Baker's claims a large group of MPs would act against the PM's Brexit proposals in the Commons, claiming there is "no alternative" plan to Mrs May's.He told Sky News: "I would make the case to my colleagues and to the public that the Chequers deal is the way we can deliver on the referendum result, respect the integrity of the UK and the Good Friday Agreement and to ensure that we are in a strong position to grow economically in the years ahead."This is a process that's going to require compromises from all sides and I think it's really important that we go forward with the Chequers proposal because, frankly, there isn't an alternative that is put on the table by the critics of Chequers.

story: Ms Hughes, a former chair of the remuneration committee at Royal Bank of Scotland, has been a director of companies including Cable & Wireless Worldwide, Reuters Group, Wm Morrison and Vodafone.She now chairs The Gym Group and iQ Student Accommodation, a privately owned business backed by Goldman Sachs. title: jo coxs message pushed people out of their tents at tory glastonbury
story: An even more surprising figure arrived in the shape of George Osborne - fresh off the red-eye flight from New York - who called up last minute and insisted on speaking.It was shocking how in all their political differences, it was the murdered MP for Batley and Spen's message that rang through all eight tents. The aim was to reach out to ordinary people of all political persuasions - and none, organiser George Freeman MP told me.That was immediately clear from the wacky "scribble wall", a 10 metre-long canvas where attendees were encouraged to express themselves.Underneath the caption "draw our current government as an animal" was a picture of a large mouse. Other additions included: "Love Lib Dems", "Move parliament to Birmingham" and "Bush did 9/11".,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"But then there were equally few parroting how brilliant Theresa May is.It's not that these views weren't held, but given the political dominance the Conservative and Labour leaders have, this felt like a genuine space to hear sincere debate without being told you had to pick a side. So many I spoke to paid tribute to Jo Cox, and repeated her message: "We have more in common than that which divides us."That was proved by the call from Andy Burnham, Greater Manchester's Labour mayor, for the festival to move northwards next year.

title: scientists discover three new species of snailfish in oceans deepest depths
story: Their bodies are translucent and gelatinous their only bones are tiny structures in the inner ear that are crucial for orientation.Dr Thom Linley, one of the researchers, told Sky News: "They go against the mould of what you imagine for a deep sea fish."There are no gnashing teeth or creepy bulbous eyes. They are small, pink, jelly-like fish."They look like they are smiling, and have a playful of swimming around.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2""I find them endearing. The world's deepest fish is an attractive animal!"Dr Linley said the species have been temporarily named as the pink, the blue and the purple Atacama snailfish "but that really doesn't do them justice".Scientists believe the fish have evolved to survive in the ultra-deep because they are out of reach of predators.But even 8,000m down there is plenty of food.

title: us east coast braces as florence forecast to intensify into major hurricane
story: It is too early to know the exact path the storm will take but it could hit land on Thursday, the centre added.Navy ships off Virginia's coast are getting ready to sail out of the path of the powerful hurricane and one North Carolina university has cancelled classes.People are already filling stockpiling plywood, bottled water and other supplies."Literally, they are filling buggies full of water, shopping carts full of water," a Walmart manager told local media in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"Henry McMaster, governor of South Carolina, warned the US should be braced for the hurricane to hit."Pretend, assume, presume that a major hurricane is going to hit right smack dab in the middle of South Carolina and is going to go way inshore," he said.Even if a direct blow is avoided, if Hurricane Florence slows or stalls near the shore it could cause devastating inland flooding, by unloading a foot or two of rain.Forecasters have warned of a life-threatening storm surge, along with the damage of a hurricane's high winds.

title: kevin maguire inquiry undercover policing
story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: Inquiry into undercover policing is going at a snail's paceTrade union leaders in Manchester this week and Labour figures such as Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, are entitled to be furiousShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor22:31, 9 SEP 2018Updated07:37, 10 SEP 2018NewsopinionThe inquiry is certainly taking its time"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThey are some of the fiercest injustices of our time – spying cops having sex with women, &shyinfiltrating legal campaigns and trade unions and helping bosses blacklist innocent staff. Not to mention the shameless snooping on the family of murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence. So trade union leaders in Manchester this week and Labour figures such as Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell, who champions the unlawfully blacklisted, are entitled to be furious. Four years ago Theresa May announced an inquiry into undercover policing but it is progressing at a snail’s pace.  This is the establishment’s way of fighting back to keep its dirty secrets. Heading the inquiry is retired judge and member of London’s exclusive men-only Garrick Club Sir John Mitting, 70, who concedes he may be a little old-fashioned. He lost the victims’ confidence long ago. He was pilloried as an out of touch “white, upper middle class, elderly gentleman” by their lawyer during a dramatic walkout. The treatment of women like Jessica, who claims she was deceived by undercover detectives living secret double lives, was one of the worst abuses in Scotland Yard’s history. For her the inquiry is not bringing justice. Jessica, the name she uses to protect her privacy, is suing the police.

title: deaf boy 7 hasnt been
story: NewsDeaf boy, 7, hasn't been to school for EIGHT MONTHS after council 'loses important paperwork'Jenson Lindop Lamens became deaf after contracting meningitis when he was 16 months old and now needs specialist care - which his parents say he is not gettingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAnna Slater19:36, 9 SEP 2018Updated19:37, 9 SEP 2018NewsJenson Lindop Lamens with mum, Jenny, and dad, Richard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A little boy who is deaf has not been at school for eight months because council bosses have lost important paperwork.  Seven-year-old Jenson Lindop Lamens' frustrated parents, Richard and Jenny, took him out of school in December because they say he was not receiving the help he needs. He requires specialist signing and bilingual help but he was becoming increasingly upset at not being able to communicate with his teachers or friends. But fast forward eight months and he has still not been given a place. His family have accused Cheshire East Council for failing to complete vital paperwork that stopped them getting a new school place for Jenson. The local authority is legally required to keep an up-to-date ‘manual’ of the education and health care requirements for every special needs child. Richard and Jenny say this has not been updated since December 2015 and therefore doesn’t include a later review which stated he needs sign language support. They claim that stopped a school just four miles from his old one taking Jenson on because they needed to see evidence in his plan that he needs British Sign Language support.  Jenny told the Crewe Chronicle : “The paperwork from the meeting last September, where it was agreed that Jenson would be entitled to full-time one-to-one signing support, seems to have mysteriously gone missing.   So that information is not going to be put into his plan because, according to Cheshire East, it doesn’t exist. “But it does exist. We’ve got emails from his old school to say that they were trying to put it in place because of the meeting, but Cheshire East are just refusing to put it in his EHCP  because apparently they don’t have any evidence he needs to sign.” She added: “The school can’t accept him until his paperwork says this child needs this. If I consult with another school they’re going to say exactly the same to me and its not because that school is not appropriate for Jenson, it’s because his paperwork doesn’t reflect the child that he is.”  Jenson suffered brain damage and hearing loss when he contracted meningitis when he was just 16 months old.  Jenny also claims the local authority made no contact despite Jenson being taken out school. She said: “We took him out of school without one single email or phone call from Cheshire East to say ‘why’s your son out of education?' “I reported myself to child welfare in March to say, ‘can you please come and prosecute me or do something because my child’s out of education and Cheshire East won’t do anything’. “I don’t think it should take three months for somebody to chase up the safety and welfare of a child.”

title: diana marriage letters philip prince
story: NewsDiana's letters from Prince Philip reveal he and the Queen 'never dreamed' Charles would leave her for Camilla"I cannot imagine anyone in their right mind would leave you for Camilla"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBronwen Weatherby22:46, 8 SEP 2018Updated09:35, 10 SEP 2018NewsPrincess Of Wales, the People's Princess was loved by a nation but not by her husband Charles "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Charles and Princess Diana's split 26 years ago shocked the world. It is believed that the Queen wrote to the unhappy married couple to recommend they divorce. But Prince Philip openly took his daughter-in-law's side when things got messy between her and Charles, and unearthed correspondence between himself and Diana show what he really thought of his son divorcing the People's Princess. In a letter written in 1992, Philip told Diana of his and the Queen's disapproval of their son's love life, RSVP live reports .  The unearthed letters, set out Philip's disapproval of his son's love life, calling him silly for risking everything with Camilla for a man in his position. Signed lovingly with fondest love, Pa, Philip wrote: We never dreamed he might feel like leaving you for her. I cannot imagine anyone in their right mind would leave you for Camilla. Such a prospect never even entered our heads. Philip also expressed his sympathy and support to Diana and offered to become a mediator in the war that raged on between her and her estranged husband Charles.  He mentioned in the letter: I can only repeat what I’ve said before, if invited, I will always do my utmost to help you and Charles to the best of my ability. But I am quite ready to concede that I have no talent as a marriage counsellor. Diana confided in her private secretary at the time Patrick Jephson, who said the support of her in-laws had meant a lot to her. Patrick said: Here at last was written proof that this was acknowledged, recognised, and there was sympathy for her. Although Philip was sympathetic to the situation, he also made it clear to Diana that he would not support her having new romantic relationships.  He wrote: We do not approve of either of you having lovers. He also said Diana was partly to blame for the breakdown of her and Charles' marriage. Can you honestly look into your heart and say that Charles's relationship with Camilla had nothing to do with your behaviour towards him in your marriage?” he added.  Details of Charles and Diana's rocky marriage was revealed to the public for the first time during the period these letters were written. And in 1992, a number of royal scandals took place, keeping the family in the public eye for the rest of the year. In March of that year, Prince Andrew and Sarah 'Fergie' Ferguson separated, and a couple of months later Fergie was photographed sucking American tycoon John Bryan's toes while on holiday.  In April, Princess Anne announced that she would be divorcing Captain Mark Phillips. And if all of this wasn't dramatic enough, intimate telephone conversations between Princess Diana and close friend James Gibney were leaked and published by The Sun. In the private phonecalls, Diana suggested to James that her situation with Charles and Camilla was like something that would happen to a character in EastEnders.

story: NewsMan with facial malformation was branded "alien" at school and hoped he would die on operating tableEXCLUSIVE: Rory McGuire has had 20 operations since he was a child -now he wants to educate othersShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRhian Lubin21:19, 9 SEP 2018Updated21:46, 9 SEP 2018NewsRory McGuire was born with a venous malformation on his lip, caused by abnormally formed veins that can enlarge as the body grows"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was the day before the first &shyoperation on Rory McGuire’s facial malformation that had caused him years of torment and bullying. The 17-year-old didn’t know if he could carry on – not only with the surgery but with life itself. For all his young life Rory had put up with being called “freak” and “alien”. The constant insults had become so bad that in his darkest hour he thought dying on the operating table would not be the worst thing that could happen. Rory, now 24, described that shocking moment. He says: “I felt so low at that point I thought if I died, all the mental pain I’d had to endure would be over. “For someone at 17 years old that’s obviously an awful way to be thinking. I was told I was a freak. I was compared to an alien. I don’t think people realise how much that can get to someone, especially a young boy.” Rory, from Ayr in west Scotland, is recalling that time to remind bullies of the harm they inflict and, importantly, to assure others in his situation that there is always hope.  With astonishing resilience and strength, and the support of friends and family, Rory endured 20 operations. But, most bravely of all, he is &shyovercoming those who mocked him by campaigning for more awareness of the effects of bullying, educating on discrimination and inspiring others. He is highlighting the prejudice he has faced by fronting the Changing Faces Hate Crime Campaign. Rory is working with the police to raise awareness of how people with &shydisfigurements are protected by UK hate crime law. Now he has been &shyshortlisted for Young Upstander at the No2H8Crime Awards. Thursday’s awards ceremony, hosted by TV presenter and social commentator June Sarpong MBE, is held to reward people and organisations which have been exceptional in fighting hate crime.  For Rory, born with a venous malformation on his lip, caused by abnormally formed veins that can enlarge as the body grows, it is a &shybrilliant platform to highlight again how devastating hate can be. He says: “I haven’t had it easy over the past few years, juggling lots of &shyoperations with having to deal with ignorance and prejudice because I look a little different. “The mental side of the abuse I had to face really halted my &shydevelopment from a teenager into a young man. On the morning of my 21st birthday I spent around two hours crying. “Because it is seen as a big milestone age that is normally celebrated in a big way. But, instead, I was upset I had reached that age and was still having to go through prejudice. “I didn’t have the confidence to go out. If I did go out, I’d experience prejudice and that would make me feel really bad about myself. It was really hard to deal with the constant staring from people of all ages. But now I’m at the point where I accept what I look like. “I’m trying to teach people that no matter what you look like you shouldn’t put anyone through any sort of prejudice.” A big part of his acceptance has come from wanting to educate those who tormented him, rather than seeking revenge.  He says: “I’d try to educate them, to make them see the error of their ways. I’d tell them what they did to me really, really hurt me.” Now, alongside his campaign work, Rory lives a full life, working for a medical &shyinsurance company, as well as enjoying his passion for golf. He also has a supportive girlfriend, Isabel, 20, who will be attending the awards with him. He says: “I’m really excited and overwhelmed to be shortlisted. “I’ve had a look at the other people who are up for nominations and they’re all so inspirational. They do such great work that I’m just happy to be mentioned in the same sentence as them.

story: NewsopinionMiriam Stoppard: Religion may give you four more years to liveAnalysis by researchers at Ohio University, US, has shown religious people live about four years longer than agnostics and atheistsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMiriam Stoppard21:36, 9 SEP 2018NewsopinionDr Miriam Stoppard considers whether faith can help your health "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Emailt’s well-known leading a spiritual life promotes longevity, but now a team of academics reckon they have nailed just how much longer you could live. Analysis by researchers at Ohio University, US, has shown religious people live about four years longer than agnostics and atheists.  After analysing more than 1,500 obituaries from across the US, the team, including an associate professor of psychology, Christian End, concluded the difference between worshippers and those who weren’t part of a religious group could be  down to a mix of social support, stress-relieving practices and abstaining from unhealthy habits.  The records they studied included religious affiliations and marriage details as well as information on &shyactivities, hobbies and habits, which can help or hinder our health, not usually found in census data.  The study found that, on average, people whose obituary mentioned they were religious lived an extra 5.64 years. Life expectancy was 3.82 years longer in religious people when they took into consideration marriage rates, a factor which has been shown to increase life expectancy and help stave off disease. “The study provides persuasive evidence there is a relationship between religious participation and how long a person lives,” said Dr Baldwin Way, co-author of the study and &shyassociate professor of psychology. The major part of the study used more than 1,000 obituaries from &shynewspapers in 42 states. But a further analysis of 500 obituaries from the Des Moines Register, a newspaper in Iowa, US, found the effect was more pronounced and religion was &shyassociated with an extra 6.48 years of life, suggesting living in a more &shyreligious community might have an extra effect.

title: mum who thought stressed after
story: NewsMum who thought she was stressed after forgetting important details at work given devastating diagnosisAfter Marie, 58, was sent for a number of tests, she was told the shocking news that 'turned her life upside down'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySimon Murfitt09:03, 10 SEP 2018NewsMarie and Mark Bentley after he completed the London Marathon "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who thought she was stressed after beginning to forget important details at work was shocked to receive a devastating diagnosis. Marie Bentley, 58, had worked for a local authority for more than 30 years since leaving school and prided herself on remembering complex information needed for her job. It was when she found she could not recall details of legislation that she first noticed her symptoms.  But after going to see her GP and being sent for a number of tests her life was turned upside down, the Hertfordshire Mercury reports.   She and her husband Mark, who live in Sawbridgeworth, Hertfordshire, with their 16-year-old daughter Alex, were given the devastating news that she had been diagnosed with progressive semantic dementia.  It was so unexpected and so very sad, said Mark, recalling the day the couple were given the news in 2014. We were not at all prepared for this diagnosis. We came out of the appointment completely shell-shocked.  Semantic dementia is a form of frontotemporal dementia, or FTD. It is rare, with just 16,000 people in the UK thought to be affected. It is a form of dementia that can often affect younger people, typically in their 40s, 50s and 60s, and its symptoms are progressive. Marie's GP initially thought her symptoms might be as a result of stress and signed her off work for two weeks, the Hertfordshire Mercrury reports. When he reviewed her two weeks later, he recommended a further two weeks off work and in the meantime arranged for a home assessment team to visit her. He must have suspected she had dementia, but he was not explicit about this to Marie and her family at the time, according to the report.  She was then referred to The National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in Queen Square, London, a leading centre for diseases of the brain, spine and nervous system.  Mark attended the appointment with Marie, which involved numerous tests over the course of a day. Two weeks later they returned to the hospital where they were given the news of Marie's diagnosis. No treatment or cure is available for the condition and Marie was advised not to return to work as stress could accelerate the degeneration of her brain. Despite taking early retirement, Marie stays in regular contact with her colleagues, as well as staying active, going to the gym and taking long walks with friends.  “Marie keeps herself busy. She might spend a bit more time doing things like the family food shopping, making sure that she can describe the things she needs to buy if the words escape her, said Mark. She gets by and her independence is important to her. Early signs of the disease are quite subtle, such as difficulty finding words and understanding the meaning of words that would have been previously known or forgetting what objects are for. Unlike Alzheimer’s disease, people in the early stages of semantic dementia would not normally have problems with their day-to-day memory or their ability to find their way around. On turning 50, Mark has taken on a series of challenges to raise money for The National Brain Appeal, a charity that raises funds for The National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery in London, where Marie was diagnosed and where she is taking part in research. One of these events is the Thames Path Challenge, where Mark will attempt to run 100km in one day. Mark will start the Thames Path Challenge at 8am on Saturday, 8 September, and is hoping to complete the race in around 12 hours. The route starts at Putney Bridge in South West London and follows the River Thames all the way to Henley in Oxfordshire. Mark’s son Tom, who lives in London, will be there to cheer him on. “This is the biggest challenge I have ever taken on, said Mark, a self-employed carpenter. I ran the London Marathon in four and a half hours in 2017 and so far this year I have taken part in a half marathon and a ten kilometre race. He added: 100km is quite a leap but I’m up for giving it a go and have been doing a lot of training for it.”

title: paraglider learning walk again after
story: NewsParaglider learning to walk again after horror accident that killed friend when they plunged 70ft to earthNick Roberts' friend died after their parachutes became entwined and they crashed mid air and they went plummeting 70ft to the groundShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLisa Porter22:31, 9 SEP 2018NewsNick Roberts before the accident "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A paraglider crashed into his friend mid-air and plummeted 70ft to the ground in a horro accident.  Nick Roberts was left with devastating injuries when his parachute became entwined with a friend's and the pair fell to the ground within seconds. Mr Roberts lay helpless, in pain, on the ground and not knowing how seriously he was injured. His friend was laid near him. He did not survive - and Mr Roberts, 47, was left with lasting injuries. The pair had been motor paragliding with four others over a field in Peterborough on the day of the crash. A witness who was at ground level when the collision occurred called emergency services.  Ambulances arrived soon afterwards, followed by two air ambulances, Lincolnshire Live reported.    Mr Roberts was airlifted to Queen's Medical Centre in Nottingham and, sadly, his friend died at the scene.  Self-employed builder Mr Roberts had extensive and serious injuries including a broken back, broken ribs, broken knee and an injury to his ankle that was so severe that a bone was sticking out through his skin, leaving doctors questioning if he would survive. He also suffered other multiple injuries. Mr Roberts underwent three days of surgery with six hours spent on cleaning up his ankle. Recalling the day Mr Roberts said: “I turned left when on the paramotor in the sky and he was there in front of me. It happened so fast. I remember thinking ‘this is going to hurt.’  We hit the ground within seconds. I think my feet hit the floor first and I felt my back and legs break. I could hear my friend breathing when we were on the ground and the paramedics came. People are unaware of how important the air ambulance is until they need it. They flew me straight to Nottingham. “I had no idea how serious the injuries were at first. I remember the air ambulance landing but I cannot remember much after that. They told me they couldn’t say if I would be able to walk again but I can walk. It’s small steps at the moment but I am getting there. Mr Roberts spent three weeks in hospital with his family fearing the worst for the first 10 days.  His family had been told he may not survive due to the extent of his injuries. But Mr Roberts is on the mend and is undergoing physiotherapy to aid his walking. Mr Roberts’ wife Jodie, 43, and their four children Jack, 21, Joe, 19, Grace, 15, and Amy, 14 have been supporting him in his rehabilitation. Mrs Roberts said: “It was the bank holiday weekend, when the police came knocking at the door. I’ll never forget it, they said are you the wife of Mr Roberts? I replied ‘yes.’ They said your husband has been involved in a collision and I asked them if it was in the sky or on the ground. They replied ‘the sky.’  “They told me he had received life-changing injuries and I needed to go to the hospital straight away. They didn’t know what the injuries were so I had no idea what to expect. They blue-lighted in a car to Nottingham. When we arrived a nurse was pushing someone on a stretcher and that person put their hand in the air. I knew it was Nick. “It was a very worrying time for all of the family as we had been told to expect the worst.” Mrs Roberts took time off work to care for her husband at home and has recently returned. They say that they have been overwhelmed by the support of locals, namely the Wayne and Julie Salmon who are the landlords of the Hammer and Pincer Pub.

story: NewsUnited Airlines passengers stunned to see pilot take off clothes and fall asleep in first classUnited Airlines said the flight was under the control of a three-man cockpit crew and pilots are required to take a rest break on trans-Atlantic flightsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByHeather GreenawayElaine McCahill21:47, 9 SEP 2018Updated07:12, 10 SEP 2018NewsPassengers on a Glasgow-bound United Airlines flight were shocked when a pilot took a NAP in first class "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPassengers of a plane bound for Glasgow from New Jersey were left shocked when a pilot took off his uniform and went for a nap in first class. The United Airlines pilot took a rest an hour into the seven hour long trans-Atlantic journey from Newark, New Jersey. Concerned passengers were worried that the pilot's actions posed a safety risk. The incident happened on flight UA161, which left Liberty International Airport at 7.40pm on August 22 and arrived in Glasgow Airport at 7.30am the next day. The flight was under the control of a three-man cockpit crew.  A retired police inspector who now works as a security adviser took a photo of the captain after he laid out his uniform and nodded off in bed. He told the Daily Record : “The captain went to the loo and changed into a T-shirt before going for a sleep in first class. “When he woke up, he changed back into his uniform and radioed for access back to the cockpit. “Police officers get a hard time when they are photographed sleeping in a patrol car. “I don’t think the captain of a flight packed with hundreds of people should be in such a vulnerable position. “He slept for an hour and a half, then the first officer went for a sleep. The flight was about seven hours. “Surely if pilots are in need of a rest mid-flight, they should do it away from the passengers. I’ve travelled to the US many times and have never witnessed this.” A cabin crew member who works for a major airline, who wished to remain anonymous, said: “This is not a procedure I recognise. “It seems highly unusual for a captain to remove his uniform during a flight.

title: pontins cleaner given 20 minutes
story: NewsPontins worker 'given 20 minutes to clean filthy chalets with vomit-filled sinks and towels covered in POO'Joel Leaver, worked at the Pontins Prestatyn Sands site in Wales from 2013 to 2015, and says cleaners faced an 'uphill battle' as some rooms hadn't been updated 'in 40 years'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill18:30, 9 SEP 2018Updated18:39, 9 SEP 2018NewsA Pontins cleaner has told of how he was given '20 minutes' to clean 'filthy' chalets "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former cleaner at a Pontins resort has told of how he was given just 20 minutes to clean 'filthy chalets'. Joel Leaver worked as a cleaner at the Prestatyn Sands site in Wales from 2013 to 2015 - and describes cleaning sinks 'blocked with vomit and towels covered in faeces' - sometimes with NO gloves. It comes after numerous complaints throughout the summer regarding hygiene standards at the holiday operator's sites. Just days ago, council chiefs ordered for the pool at the Prestatyn resort to be closed with pictures showing the state it was in before being shut down. Another family claimed their chalet at the same resort in Wales was 'like a crack den' .  Writing for Wales Online , Joel told of how he started as an accommodation assistant or cleaner at the complex when he was 17. Joel worked there during school holidays and odd weekends between 2013 and 2015, originally earning &pound3.72 an hour, which was increased to &pound5.03 when he turned 18. Joel said: In my opinion, the site was out-dated and a little decrepit and needing serious attention. The general feel was that it wasn't very well looked after, and it seemed like a set from a drama televised decades ago.  Whilst I was employed there, I watched Holiday on the Buses, which was filmed there in the 70s. Some of the bathrooms I was cleaning were identical to those in the film. Rooms appeared to have been left untouched, in some cases, for at least 40 years. Joel said he and his fellow cleaners were fighting an uphill battle every day and had just 20 minutes to clean each chalet. He said: Ovens, for example, were already so dirty that we couldn't possibly get them looking much better.  We could clean the floor and wipe down surfaces, but that was the extent of our role we glossed over the cracks and problems that were already present. It would take more than some diluted cleaning spray or a mop to fix the major issues. Cleaners at the camp were paired up on most shifts, and it was expected that each chalet would be cleaned within 20 minutes. On average, most chalets included a bathroom, kitchen, big living room space and between one and two bedrooms. Staff were also expected to stock up the chalets with pillows and any missing kitchen utensils as well, and bedding needed to be rolled up neatly. Recalling a particularly gruesome incident, Joel said: One time myself and my partner found a sink blocked with vomit.  As well as time consuming, this is also unacceptable - nobody should be left to clean that up except the person themselves. It was probably one of the many chalets left with cans and bottles scattered all across the floor from yet another group of partying guests. Another time, we turned up to find several towels in the bath that were covered in faeces. I'll never know what really happened although I had to clean the mess up, gagging during each second of it. There were numerous occasions when gloves would be out of stock - and so we cleaned this sort of thing without them sometimes.  Even though he was 17 and fairly physically fit at the time, Joel said it was hard to get everything done in the allotted time and that it was particularly hard on older staff members. He continued: Most people could easily spend the whole 20 minutes on a bathroom or kitchen, especially if particularly dirty. Cleaners were poorly equipped, lacking the supplies that we needed. Cleaning products were weak, and when we did receive some branded alternatives once, they were scarce and their inclusion didn't last long.  The vacuum cleaners were outdated, to the extent that they were pretty heavy and fairly useless. I remember at a training session, probably in 2015, I was told that &pound1 million had been made in the last year. Did I see a pay rise because of it? No. Did the site get any major revamp? Absolutely not. This wasn't a business that was struggling to stay afloat. It was making money, yet the site and staff never reaped any benefits from this.

story: NewsPrince Harry had 'tear on cheek' meeting the mum of a soldier comrade who killed himselfPrince Harry greeted Maria Hunt with a big hug months after her son and his friend, Warrant Officer Nathan Hunt, took his own life after PTSD battleShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAnna Slater19:47, 9 SEP 2018Updated20:04, 9 SEP 2018NewsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle at Westminster Central Hall on Thursday "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Prince Harry had a tear in his eye as he met the mother of one of his Afghanistan comrades months after he took his own life. It starred Melissa Joan Hart as Sabrina Spellman - a schoolgirl with special powers who comes from a long line of witches. But many fans felt the real star of the show was her super-sarcastic talking black cat 'Salem'. Millions of viewers dreamed of having their very own magical moggie like him. And that was exactly why Sam and his family ended up recently adopting a black cat called Coco from Cat's Protection. Speaking as part of Purina and Cats Protection's Unadoptables campaign - which celebrates the fact no cat is unadoptable - Sam explained: My wife Lara had always wanted a black cat. Where it was once superstition and the fear of bad luck, a growing trend to why black cats are often overlooked is because apparently, they don’t photograph well for people’s social feeds.
