title: safety-expert-it-was-just-luck-that-celtic-park-crush-wasnt-more-serious
story: Professor Dr Keith Still said catastrophic organisational failures had put supporters' lives at risk ahead of the Old Firm match.  Mr Still examined video and photo evidence and fans' testimonies, and visited Celtic Park to look at the concourse at Janefield Road where the North Stand overhangs the road.  He said it was clear "three times" the safe amount of fans were packed into the area last Sunday.  Five fans were hurt and dozens had to climb over fences and walls to escape the crush as panic spread through the crowd.  Both the police and the club are investigating the incident.  Celtic announced on Friday that they have drafted in safety consultants to carry out an independent review.  Mr Still, a professor of crowd science at Manchester politan University, told the Sunday Mail: "The density of fans appears to be six to seven people per square metre - three times the maximum safe level of about two per square metre.  "At too high density, any trip, slip or fall means people do not have the opportunity to react safely - and this can have a catastrophic effect.  "It's just luck that the outcome wasn't worse."  Chief Superintendent Brian McNulty, divisional commander for Greater Glasgow, said the safety of fans is an "absolute priority".  He praised staff on the ground that day for "acting quickly" to prevent the situation worsening, adding: "We will continue to work with Celtic FC and with supporters to learn from Sunday and improve future operations."  Celtic said it has instructed Fairhurst, consultants in sports event safety management, to examine the incident and urged any fans with information to come forward.

title: new-technology-should-mean-shorter-working-week-and-better-wages
story: Frances O&rsquoGrady, general secretary of the Trades Union Congress , has called for a four-day week for workers, allowing them to share in the wealth generated by technological advances.  She will tell the TUC Congress in Manchester today: &ldquoIn the 19th century, unions campaigned for an eight-hour day. In the 20th century, we won the right to a two-day weekend and paid holidays.  &ldquoSo, for the 21st century, let&rsquos lift our ambition again.  &ldquoI believe that in this century we can win a four-day working week, with decent pay for everyone.  &ldquoIt&rsquos time to share the wealth from new technology. Not allow those at the top to grab it for themselves.  &ldquoWe need strong unions with the right to go into every workplace - starting with Amazon&rsquos warehouses here in the UK.  Research by the TUC showed that most workers expect only managers and shareholders to reap the benefits of new technology.  However, the survey of over 2,000 workers also found that four out of five employees want to cut their working hours without losing any pay as new technology makes work more efficient.  The TUC believes moves should be put in place to try to cut the working week to four days over the course of this century.  In her speech, Ms O&rsquoGrady accused employers of making staff work unpredictable or unsocial hours because of an &ldquoalways on culture.  She added that too many firms were using technology to treat workers unfairly.  The general secretary said: &ldquoBosses and shareholders must not be allowed to hoover up all the gains from new technology for themselves.  &ldquoWorking people deserve their fair share - and that means using the gains from new technology to raise pay and allow more time with their families.  &ldquoIf productivity gains from new technology are even half as good as promised then the country can afford to make working lives better.  However, while unions believe there are potential gains to be made from new technology, they also have concerns about robots and machinery replacing workers.  A report published earlier this year also warned that the UK is lagging behind other nations in terms of readiness for increased automation.  Pat Rafferty, Scottish Secretary of Unite, has previously claimed that there are positives for workers, but warned against a &ldquonightmare scenario of machines replacing workers and cataclysmic numbers thrown out of work.  Unison have also argued that, while the impact of new technology is sometimes exaggerated by experts, strategies on automation need to be put in place now to ensure workers can transition into other roles.  The Scottish Government has already put a number of steps in place to address the issue, including further investment in digital skills, the creation of a Just Transition Commission, and a plan to provide direct support for additional business research and development.

title: why-time-could-be-right-for-tvs-queen-of-calm-to-take-dimblebys-job
story: She&rsquos fond of an occasional single malt with ice to help her unwind, or a refreshing G&ampT to perk her up.  Quite often broadcaster Kirsty Wark&rsquos social media feed will also reveal she is stuck on a train, yet again, somewhere between London and Glasgow, or on a ferry bound for her favourite spot in Arran.&nbsp  She chats to her followers about food, books, art and Chanel No.19, of which she&rsquos stockpiled around &pound600 worth, unopened, just in case supplies run dry, and which she can afford thanks to her &pound200,000 Newsnight salary.&nbsp  What you don&rsquot get &ndash not surprisingly &ndash is any hint of Kirsty Wark&rsquos political views.&nbsp  Her apparent neutrality &ndash her friends within Scottish Labour aside &ndash along with a razor-sharp mind, encyclopaedic knowledge of current affairs, calm yet, when required, extremely feisty demeanour and extremely likeable persona have placed Dumfries-born Wark among the front-runners for the hottest job in political broadcasting: the ringmaster role on the BBC&rsquos flagship Question Time.  The job becomes vacant in mid-December, when David Dimbleby hangs up his colourful tie collection and ends 25 years of pointing at slightly discombobulated audience members while attempting to describe their clothes or hairstyles without causing offence.&nbsp  But first he will be in his usual centre stage spot, when Question Time rolls into the Scottish Parliament debating chamber next month, for a programme that will form part of the Festival of Politics.  The October 11 programme is likely to be the last chance for Scots to see a master chairman at work before a new, fresh-faced presenter takes over.&nbsp  According to the bookies, that will probably be Wark, frontrunner among a Who&rsquos Who of broadcasters linked to a role said to earn Dimbleby around &pound450,000 a year.&nbsp  Challenging the 62-year-old Scot is fellow Newsnight presenter Emily Maitlis, BBC News Channel Newswatch host Samira Ahmed, daytime presenter Victoria Derbyshire, Channel 4 anchorman Krishnan Guru-Murthy and ex-Newsnight host Jeremy Paxman.&nbsp  Read more:&nbspKirsty Wark and BBC colleagues call for "urgent solutions" over gender pay gap  So, what are Glasgow-based Wark&rsquos chances? And where might she take a programme that&rsquos had just three middle-aged male presenters and barely changed format since its launch in 1979?  Jeremy Vine, who has boldly claimed his new Channel 5 show will outperform Question Time, says whoever takes over may regret the move.  &ldquoThe next person to do Question Time might like to remember that alternate presenters get universally savaged, he said recently.&nbsp &ldquoAsk Sir Robin Day&rsquos successor, Peter Sissons. By the end there was nothing left of him but his teeth.  That won&rsquot worry Wark, the daughter of a solicitor and schoolteacher who was launched into political broadcasting as host of BBC Scotland&rsquos Left, Right And Centre, a tartan version of Question Time in the 1980s.&nbsp  Since then Wark has won countless awards, calmly brought political leaders to task on Newsnight and brilliantly skewered them.  Then prime minister Margaret Thatcher was left squirming after Wark casually asked: &ldquoWhy are you so unpopular in Scotland?  According to former STV chief executive Rob Woodward, who is credited with turning around the channel and introducing Scotland Tonight, Wark could give&nbsp Question Time a much-needed shot in the arm.&nbsp  &ldquoKirsty Wark has a wonderful disarming but forceful style combined with a common touch that would without doubt extend the programme&rsquos appeal.&nbsp&nbsp  For Kezia Dugdale, former leader of Scottish Labour, the time has come for a female anchor.  &ldquoThere are a huge number of incredibly talented female presenters working at the corporation, including Kirsty Wark, Mishal Husain and Emily Maitlis, she says.&nbsp  &ldquoIn terms of guests, we need less of Nigel Farage and more of Loki and other voices from outside the political establishment &ndash while ensuring it&nbspstill holds those in power to account.  Despite criticism of &ldquodumbing down with guests that include actors and comedians, Question Time remains the UK&rsquos foremost political programme, with about 2.7million viewers.&nbsp  It hit a peak of 8.3m when Nick Griffin of the BNP appeared on the panel in 2009 &ndash a point that ushered in a new, highly controversial style of panel member, and saw Nigel Farage and opinionated historian David Starkey favoured over what some might regard as far more relevant political voices.  That, says former Scottish first minister Jack McConnell,&nbsp  now Lord McConnell of Glenscorrodale, has contributed to the programme losing its way.  &ldquoIt&rsquos deliberately moved away from a programme that expands the knowledge of the viewer, to one that has attempted to be an entertainment show in which people shout at each other.  In an age when too many media interviews are carefully controlled to produce a line for news, Question Time could play an important role. Instead, it produces zero public benefit in that context.  While reluctant to discuss his friend&rsquos potential role on the programme, his vision of the next presenter is not a million miles away from Wark.  He says: &ldquoThe role needs someone who has authority, who is well-researched and doesn&rsquot rely on research done by a team behind the scenes. It needs someone who has the potential to be seen as at least an equal to the people around the table in terms of knowledge of current affairs and credibility.  Read more:&nbsp'There's no such thing as Superwoman. But nobody needs to be invisible': Kirsty Wark on a life in broadcasting ... and busting taboos  Darren &ldquoLoki McGarvey, author of Poverty Safari, who appeared on Question Time when it visited Perth in May, says Dimbleby&rsquos role is deceptively complex.  &ldquoI found myself distracted by observing him. It&rsquos one thing watching&nbsp on television, but it&rsquos a live discussion, it&rsquos moving fast with different personalities, different history and different politics and he is moving from moment to moment. You develop a deep appreciation for his experience and why he is so effective in that role.  &ldquoKirsty Wark is the high priestess of establishment. That&rsquos not a criticism, but when we have figures with a standard BBC outlook taking the conversation, it will always exist within the same parameters.  &ldquoAny presenter of a certain stature will be able to adapt to the environment and put their own spin on it, and Kirsty Wark will be more than capable of that.  Whether she becomes the next Question Time chairwoman or not, Wark has plans to remain part of the political broadcasting scene for a long time to come.&nbsp  &ldquoI feel as empowered as ever, she said in a recent interview with The Herald. &ldquoThere are key things I want to do and I&rsquom very lucky I get to do them. You have to keep changing and developing.&nbsp

title: new-chapter-as-book-town-marks-its-20th-birthday
story: But now the Wigtown Book Festival has grown to be one of Scotland&rsquos foremost literary events and has welcomed almost a quarter of a million book lovers through its doors.  This year the festival marks its 20th anniversary, having grown from something that took place over a long weekend to a 10-day bash attended by some of the world&rsquos top authors.  Down the years, the event has welcomed literary luminaries such as Ian Rankin, Clare Balding, BBC foreign editor John Simpson and the actress Joanna Lumley, while this year&rsquos festival will be attended by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.&nbsp  Read more:&nbspAnn Cleeves on writing the final Shetland book Wild Fire  It has been made possible by an army of volunteers from across Dumfries and Galloway who have stepped up in ever-increasing numbers to make sure that the talks, book signings, films, shows and other attractions pass off without a hitch.&nbsp  &nbspMore than 150 adults and children, aged from under 10 to 80 and over, give time throughout the year carrying out an enormous range of tasks.  Most are from Dumfries and Galloway, some are from the Central Belt and in past years they have even come from America.  A special event was held at The Print Room in Wigtown this week, attended by Dumfries and Galloway Council Leader Councillor Elaine Murray, Derek Crichton director of communities and festival Operational Director Anne Barclay, and around 80 volunteers.  Anne said: &ldquoFrom its earliest days to this year&rsquos 20th event, the story of the festival has been all about the willingness and enthusiasm of the volunteers who were determined to make the festival a success and to help revive the economy of Wigtown. Over the years it has built from a small weekend event into a 10-day extravaganza that attracts authors and audiences from all across the UK and the rest of the world.  &ldquoThe volunteers do everything from delivering leaflets to stewarding events and even driving speakers backwards and forwards to railway stations and airports.&nbsp  &ldquoThey are the public face of the event &ndash they are also its body and soul. It would be impossible without them.  Read more&nbspARTS NEWS: Wigtown reveals book festival line up, Alasdair Gillies celebrations, Migration discussed at RSA  Nearly 250,000 people have attended the festival, which began in 1999, and it generates &pound3m for the local economy.  Many people love being a volunteer for the buzz of being at the heart of a community-based cultural event.  Among them is Nanette Craig, who will be 85 on the second day of the festival, and has been helping out for more than a decade. She said: &ldquoI love being part of the festival, it&rsquos great fun and it keeps you young.  Nanette moved to the area 60 years ago when she married a local farmer and they retired to a house in the town in 2002.  She added: &ldquoI love it here, there&rsquos such a strong sense of community. But the town had become so run down with empty shops and houses. It really needed a boost and that&rsquos what the festival has done.  Her volunteering duties tend to be out on the streets as &ldquoa smiling face, chatting to visitors and providing directions and information. One of the younger volunteers is Helena Cochrane, aged 13, whose family run the Old Bank Bookshop and who eagerly looks forward to the festival each year. Her roles extend from delivering leaflets to introducing speakers at events that are part of the children&rsquos festival. This time she is looking forward to catching up with the likes of Cathy Cassidy, Ross Mackenzie, Chae Strathie and Vivian French. Helena said: &ldquoI really enjoy being part of the festival, it&rsquos always been part of my life. And it&rsquos great to have the chance to meet so many authors and illustrators.  Read more:&nbspEdinburgh's Festival Fringe registers another record: 2,838,839 tickets issued  Morag Donnan, who was the head of the primary school in the nearby village of Sorbie for 20 years, provides accommodation for each year for a festival sponsor and also provides transport for visiting authors.  She began volunteering about a decade ago acting as a steward, she then began working in the box office and nowadays does an afternoon a week in the Wigtown Festival Company book shop.  She said: &ldquoI have always worked with people and I love books, so this is something I very much enjoy. And I also think it&rsquos a wonderful thing that here, in the back of beyond, we have an event that is so successful and has become well known around the world.  Morag also enjoys meeting authors and is particularly looking forward to Sally Magnusson&rsquos appearance this year.  Councillor Adam Wilson, the council&rsquos events champion, said: &ldquoThe regeneration of Wigtown has been a comprehensive community effort, based upon the efforts of volunteers.&nbsp  &ldquoThe obvious pride the book festival volunteers have for Wigtown and the event is crucial to its success and ensures visitors a warm, genuine welcome. The creativity and commitment of the Festival Company to support the Book Town initiative is an internationally significant example of rural development.  The 20th Wigtown Book Festival takes place from September 21 to 30.

title: artists-nature-dictionary-captures-how-scots-once-described-our-landscape
story: Long forgotten words to describe the countryside have been uncovered and included in a new dictionary of words compiled during academic&rsquos research in the Cairngorms.&nbsp  Dictionary author Amanda Thomson said: &ldquoThese words reveal so much about our history, natural history, and our changing ways of life - they are indicative of the depth, richness and iety of the Scots language and its unique relationship to nature and the Scottish landscapes of Lowlands, Highlands and islands.&nbsp  The visual artist and lecturer at Glasgow School of Art was researching a PhD about the landscape by speaking to foresters and ecologists in the Abernethy Forest in the Cairngorms when she began to notice unfamiliar words they were using.  At the same time, she found a 19th-century Scottish dictionary in an Edinburgh bookshop.  &ldquoI came across the word timmer breeks &ndash timmer is timber and breeks is an old Scots word for trousers and timmer breeks together means coffin, she said.  &ldquoThe more I started to look at these dictionaries I was coming across these really interesting definitions &ndash phrases I had never used.&nbsp  &ldquoA lot of the words had a real poetry to them and that&rsquos what made me collect them. There is a word huam, which means the moan of an owl in the warm days of summer, or splorroch which is the sound made by walking in wet mud.  A Scots Dictionary of Nature, which is published by Saraband, is a reminder of how easily the beauty of language and its connection with nature can be lost.&nbsp  In 2007, the Oxford Junior Dictionary ditched 40 words it said children no longer used. Acorn, otter, bluebell and willow were replaced with blog, voicemail and broadband.  The ensuing outcry led to a book called The Lost Words by author Robert Macfarlane, a fundraising campaign to get the books into schools and even an exhibition in Edinburgh this summer.&nbsp  Ms Thomson, from Kilsyth, said: &ldquoDifferent words will have resonance with different people depending on who they are, where they are from and how old they are.  &ldquoIt harks back to connections to place and history, how you relate to previous generations. There&rsquos a word for a sparrow &ndash speug &ndash I always remember my grandfather using.  &ldquoMost of us are now in the city more than the country and we don&rsquot care about the weather in the way we would have done. A lot of the old words pertain to that.&nbsp  &ldquoOne of the lovely words for rainbow is a water-gaw and when seen from the north or the east it&rsquos a sign of bad weather.  &ldquoSome of the words are really matter of fact but there is something lovely about it and they are sometimes specific. A bar-ghist is a ghost that frequents stiles &ndash there is something lovely that you have to be careful when crossing a stile because a ghost might be waiting for you.

title: the-best-people-to-study-religion-can-be-those-not-of-any-set-faith
story: But now, for the first time, a woman has taken up the post of Head of the School of Divinity at the University of Edinburgh, ending centuries of only male posteriors occupying the chair at the top of the table.  Professor Helen Bond said she hopes to bring a fresh outlook to the role and to inspire others to take a look at a subject some may regard as dusty and dry.&nbsp  A historian, published author, and scholar of the early life of Jesus, the professor was previously a lecturer at the school and will fill the top job for the next five years.  She said: &ldquoIt&rsquos something I&rsquom proud of. It&rsquos amazing that it&rsquos taken to 2018 for a woman to become the head of school here.  &ldquoThe whole school is very different to when I first came. There were far fewer women on the teaching staff, and among the students. That&rsquos all changed and now around a half are female.  She added: &ldquoI hope that other women will see this and think that the study of religion is not confined to a particular gender, or type of person.  A member of the Church of Scotland but not an ordained minister like many of her predecessors, Professor Bond intended to study maths when she was younger. She switched to theology because of an interest in the ancient East and the history of its people &ndash the Assyrians, Babylonians and Egyptians.&nbsp  A mother-of-two, she enjoys working in her pyjamas at home, belly dances in her spare time and enjoys writing things out by hand instead of rattling a keyboard.&nbsp  She is also one of the few people on the planet to have an intimate knowledge of Jesus&rsquo foreskin. While researching her book Jesus: A Very Brief History &ndash which reconstructs his life &ndash she encountered the tale that this piece of Christ&rsquos anatomy was once believed to be the only part of his earthly remains on earth following his resurrection.&nbsp  At one point, there were 18 supposed versions of this relic in ious places, although all are now long gone.&nbsp  Professor Bond&rsquos rise to the top has been at a time of change for the School, which has moved away from being the preserve of the Church of Scotland to one which welcomes people of all faiths and none.&nbsp  The 50-year-old, who says the hardest part of the job is getting used to her new electronic diary, hopes that under her leadership the School will attract those interested in religion, not the religious themselves.&nbsp  She said: &ldquoIt certainly has been [a school for the religious] in the past. A long time ago it was a Church of Scotland training school and all students were male until the 1960s, when women began coming forward to be ordained.&nbsp  &ldquoBut Church ministers in training are very much in the minority now, and only account for around five per cent of the student body.  &ldquoNow, instead of focussing on the Church of Scotland, the school teaches all religions, with none being central.  Read more:&nbspPulsar pioneer&rsquos &pound2.3m to help students  Professor Bond added: &ldquoThere are courses in ancient Buddhism, Hebrew studies, Greek, Christian and Muslim dialogue, atheism, terrorism, American Protestantism and the rise of Trump, for example. There&rsquos a huge iety of stuff.  &ldquoSometimes the best people to study religion are those who are not of a set faith.  Says she wants to make the department &ldquomore active in reaching out to the public, and to attract people &ldquowhatever their views on religion through open lectures, talks, social media and conferences.&nbsp  &ldquoThe school of divinity should be a place that engages with the public more than we have done in the past, she said.&nbsp&nbsp

title: Marianne Taylor  Creative solutions needed to save Glasgow  39 s precious CCA
story: It became horribly clear early on that Charles Rennie Mackintosh&rsquos masterpiece had been critically damaged. No one realised then, however, that the impact on its neighbours would also be utterly devastating.  You can&rsquot understate the CCA&rsquos contribution to Glasgow&rsquos cultural scene and reputation. But neither can you play down how fundamental GSA &ndash which sits just feet away - has been to this ongoing success. The two organisations share not only an outlook, networks and ideas, but personnel. A significant number of the CCA staff and many who exhibit there are students or former students of the art school. The centre&rsquos visionary director, Francis McKee, is a lecturer and researcher at GSA.  It would therefore be the most terrible irony if the CCA was forced out of business due to its close proximity to its creative twin. But this is now a real possibility.  Over the last few days we learned that the centre, which unlike other Garnethill residents and businesses was not allowed back in earlier this month, is on a financial knife-edge, facing indefinite limbo and possible ruin as no date has been given for when the west fa&ccedilade of the Mackintosh building on Scott Street will be made safe.  The frustrating reality is that the CCA - which actually comprises 13 businesses and institutions under one banner and roof &ndash currently has no control over its fate, and must watch helplessly as Glasgow City Council and GSA lay responsibility at each other&rsquos door each other for the situation. The fact is, though, while the safety of the west fa&ccedilade of the Mack remains a concern, re-opening presents a challenge for the CCA, especially since the Scott Street door is a fire exit.  Obviously, the council has a legal obligation to keep people safe. But it&rsquos vital now that all parties &ndash including Creative Scotland, which owns the CCA building &ndash come together so that energy can be put into finding creative solutions worthy of this cultural icon that would allow it to re-open, even partially, and begin to rebuild. Apportioning blame wastes time and diverts attention what we need now is focus and action to avert disaster.  I spoke to Mr McKee over the weekend and he put forward three practical solutions that could bring things back from the brink in the short term. The first is access for a plumber and builder to assess and fix a leak that has resulted in a ceiling collapse in the exhibition space. Considering the position of these facilities in the building, accompanied safe access would surely be possible?  The second is a re-assessment of fire exits to allow partial access for businesses and customers. After all, the CCA&rsquos Sauchiehall Street neighbours on either side are already back in business. Mr McKee also suggests a safety canopy over the Scott Street exit for the duration of remaining works to mitigate safety concerns.  The third part of the jigsaw is a date for the opening of the caf&eacute bar &ndash even if it is some way in the future &ndash so insurers can continue to support this busy, buzzy meeting point which supports 32 jobs.  The Scottish Government fund set up in the aftermath of the fire is very welcome and will no doubt help with cash flow to some extent. But in this case money is only part of the problem, as Mr McKee&rsquos sensible suggestions highlight. What appears to be lacking is willingness on the part of its partners and masters to really, truly stand up for this jewel in the city&rsquos cultural crown in its hour of need.  Notwithstanding who or what was to blame for the fire at the Mack, GSA must surely feel some sense of responsibility for the situation and do more to assist, not least by providing some idea of a date for completion of work on the west fa&ccedilade by its contractors. It could also perhaps leverage support from the international arts community for its close friend.  The council, for its part, must find ways around the sort of &ldquocomputer says no attitudes and policies that led to so much criticism over the last weeks and could yet contribute to a slow and painful death for the CCA. Solutions can be found where there is a will to make them happen.  Only last week council leader Susan Aitken talked of culture and the arts playing &ldquoa significant role in Sauchiehall Street&rsquos rebirth. The way to make this happen is to ensure the street&rsquos most valuable resident, the one that cities around the world envy and try to replicate, stays open. But time is running out.
